 One thing that most Americans don't realize is that the Muslim community here in the US is far more moderate than that in most European countries. Apart from some differences in demographics of the source of Muslim migration, a large part of the difference lies in how they are treated in their respective countries. Here, in the US, Muslims are generally well integrated and there is no significant difference in average standard of living between Muslims and non-Muslims. The fact that we are a nation of immigrants helps in this assimilation. In many European countries, on the other hand, the Muslim communities (which also generally constitute a much larger percentage of the population) are generally marginalized both socially and economically. Such marginalization can breed resentment and keep populations more isolated and less likely to assimilate, as they generally have in the US. That is a situation ripe for such fundamentalist Muslim sects to flourish since they sattisfy many of the angry reactions that these marginalized communities have against the West. This, in turn, further isolates these communities from their native populations - a vicious cycle.
 
 So, whoever you consider is at fault (the Muslims or the native communities), the reality is that the Islamic communities in Europe are typically far more extremist than in the US and very restrictive attitudes about women's rights and gay rights prevail.  "This adaptation should be encouraged in every way possible. Muslim immigrants should not only be taught the language of their adopted country; they should be comprehensively educated in the ways of democracy. They must learn-no small order-to think for themselves, to read critically, to question. Most important, they must learn to question those things they have been taught to regard as most sacred. And they must be encouraged to see themselves as free individuals in a free land rather than as members of a straitjacketing subculture whose religion obliges them to take their marching orders from autocratic community leaders.
 
 Finally, these immigrants must be thought of-and must be encouraged to think of themselves-as full and equal members of the societies in which they live. European natives must appreciate what an accomplishment it is for people to become functioning members of societies radically different from the ones in which they were born. Those who do make the adjustment successfully deserve the utmost respect. To persist in calling them immigrants after they have been living and working in a country for years (and, even more outrageously, to use the same word to describe their European-born children and grandchildren) is not only offensive and insulting but staggeringly counterproductive. 
 
 As for those who, after a period in the West, make it obvious that they are unwilling or unable to adapt, they must be sent home and replaced by deserving individuals who can adapt. This may appear extreme, but there is no reasonable alternative. For at stake in all this, ultimately, are the basic freedoms of all Westerners-not only women and homosexuals, but everyone, including Muslims and former Muslims who wish to live in a place where they can be themselves. At stake, indeed, is Western civilization."

It seems that any education of Muslims in Europe needs to be handled very carefully. I can imagine that it would be quite difficult to teach them "to question those things they have been taught to regard as most sacred" without being accused of purposely trying to subvert the religion itself. 
 
 The same delicate balance seems to be played out in issues where Christianity and Science clash. For example, when Evolution is taught, I don't believe that it is bluntly stated in these classes that the religious view of Creation is wrong. It simply presents its evidence and asks people to judge for themselves. Such a subtler approach might not work with strongly devout fundamentalist Muslims, as it does not work with strongly devout Evangelical Christians. 
 
 So, if a blunter method needs to be used, then how does one go about doing that while maintaining that one has a stance of freedom of religion? If one picks and chooses various points in the religion against which to argue, then how does one decide on those points and does one use the same criteria for criticizing similar points in all religions - including Christianity? Again, it would be a delicate balance and require a lot of rethinking of how religion is treated in a secular society.

 The youths, aged 13 to 15, allegedly attacked their victim as she walked home from school in the Charlottenburg district which is generally seen as safe area with low crime rates.
 
 While allegedly gang-raping the girl, the youths are reported to have filmed the sexual attack with a mobile phone camera. Media reports say the four later boasted about the rape to other school children and sent copies of the video to friends.
 
 Police who detained the four earlier this week have so far not found any film footage of the alleged rape. There is suspicion the video pictures may have been erased and mobile phones of the suspects are being analysed by experts in a bid to retrieve any pictures....
 
 Adding to the potential explosiveness of the alleged rape is the fact that the four suspects are all the children of immigrant families, while the victim is German. The normally well-informed Bild tabloid said the suspects were two German-Turks, a German Russian and a German-Angolan.
 
 Federal police statistics released on Monday show non-German youths under the age of 21 were twice as likely to be crime suspects last year than German nationals of the same age.
 
 Officers in charge of the case are convinced the four youths carried out the gang rape and DNA tests are being carried out on sperm traces found on the victim.
 
 Given the brutality of the attack, there has been anger over a decision by Berlin justice officials to order the youths be set free. The 13-year-old suspect is too young to be kept in detention under German law, but the other three could be held.
 
 Berlin justice Senator Karin Schubert insists, however, that even youths suspected of violent crimes can only be kept locked up if there is danger they will flee justice.

 If there do exist statistics that show that a particular group is over-represented in crimes (be it Muslims in Europe or African Americans in the US), then one has a choice of how to react:
 
 1) One can stereotype all members of that group as being violent ... that would be both racist and idiotic. I don't think anyone here is claiming that.
 
 2) One can claim that even the statement of those statistics is itself a racist act and we should, instead, ignore those statistics ... that would be illogical and unproductive, but something that is done far too often.
 
 or
 
 3) We can analyze the reasons behind those statistics and try to find a solution.

However, there are some more independent sources that do show alarming trends in rape in Scandinavia - at least some of which are attributed to rising crime rates by immigrants. Unfortunately, Googling "Muslim rape Sweden" or "immigrant rape Sweden" gave almost no official sources - mainly blogs - so it seems hard to find any official statistics, positive or negative, on the subject to either confirm or deny the trends. 
 
 Official Swedish statistics do reveal that the number of reported consummated rapes has tripled over the last two decades - from a report from Bra, the Swedish National Council for Crime Prevention: http://www.bra.se/extra/faq/?module_instance=2&action=question_show&id=292&category_id=9 , section on trends. This is as official as one can get. However, it says nothing there about ethnic background.
 
 In Oslo, the capital of Norway, a police investigation into the ethnicity of rape suspects did reveal that the majority were of foreign heritage, which in Norway generally means Muslims: http://www.aftenposten.no/english/local/article190268.ece . 
 
 Statistics from Denmark are similar: http://www.cphpost.dk/get/62173.html
 where in that articles it states: "His theory is backed up by a 1998 Justice Ministry survey on crime, which found that immigrants were over-represented by an average of 46 per cent. In addition, the recent publication of a report from the Copenhagen police shows that 47.5 per cent of prisoners on remand for serious crimes such as murder, attempted murder and rape come from immigrant backgrounds." Also, "'Those immigrants who do commit rape belong to a hardcore group who have been considerably marginalised and alienated and who are extremely criminally inclined already. These are people who don't care what happens to them as they feel things can't get any worse anyway. They simply use and abuse others as it suits them. But even if we compare this group with other Danish-born people in the same situation, i.e. with no job and no prospects, the immigrant group is still over-represented.'"
 
 These are isolated police and government reports, but they do show some very disturbing trends - at least in the cities where poor and marginalized people would generally reside. The statistics in the countryside could be much different. Unfortunately, it is hard to find a wider range of statistics to prove things one way or the other. If Muslim immigrants are not overrepresented in rape statistics, then it would make every sense to explore and publish those statistics. However, if they are generally over-represented then it is frustrating but somewhat understandable that such statistics should be not be explored. On seeing such statistics, I would advocate trying to increase police action to curb the actions of the minority of extremists that commit such crimes. Unfortunately, I am sure that much of the Scandinavian populations would use it as another excuse for across-the-board racism against Muslims.

 That seems to happen so often in threads. They might start off in reasonable debate, but then they nearly always degenerate into flames. I think it is due to people's desire to have the last word and to think that they "won" the arguement if they have the last word - no matter how ridiculous the arguement. So, a lone flaming post starts an arguement that grows and grows until it takes over the whole thread - a pity.
 
 I personally prefer to ignore flamers. For the most part, they are not worth the trouble of responding. I generally try to only respond to posters who do make at least some effort at actual debate. The most frustrating tend to be the occasional posters who mix flaming with actual points.
 
 By the way, do you know of a forum that is less prone to such degradation of threads into flames? A few years ago when I first joined, I found this to be such a forum, but it seems to have degraded.
